section.title: Overview
section.para: This modules is a gateway between Openser and a jabber server. It enables the exchange of instant messages between SIP clients and XMPP(jabber) clients.
The gateway has two modes to run:

listitem.para: the component-mode - the gateway requires a standalone XMPP server amd the 'xmpp' module acts as a XMPP component

the server-mode - the module acts itself as a XMPP server, no requirement for another XMPP server in the system. NOTE: this is limited implementation of a XMPP server, it does not support SRV or TLS so far. This mode is in beta stage for the moment.

section.para: In the component mode, you need a local XMPP server (recommended Jabberd2); the xmpp module will relay all your connections to a tcp connection to the local jabber server. The documentation and the source for a Jabber server are located at the following link: http://jabberd.jabberstudio.org/2/#download
After you have a running XMPP server, what you need to do is set the following parameters in the Openser configuration file:

listitem.para: gateway_domain, xmpp_domain (which can be the same as gateway_domain) and xmpp_host, which are explained in the Exported Parameters section;
in the following section of the configuration file, change to your gateway domain:
you can also change the jabber server password, which must be the same as the xmpp_password parameter.

section.para: A use case, for the component-mode, would look like this:

listitem.para: the gateway is running on sip-xmpp.openser.org;
the jabber server is running on xmpp.openser.org;
the component is running on xmpp-sip.openser.org.

section.para: In the server mode, the xmpp module is a minimal jabber server, thus you do not need to install another jabber server, the gateway will connect to the jabber servers, where the users you want to chat with have an account.
If you want to change to server-mode, you have to change the "backend" parameter, as shown in the Exported Parameters section, from component to server.
A use case, for the server-mode, would look like this:

listitem.para: the gateway is running on sip-xmpp.openser.org;
the "XMPP server" is running on xmpp-sip.openser.org.

section.title: domain_separator (string)
section.para: In the destination address we need an extra character as a domain separator, apart from @. The address of the XMPP(jabber) client looks like this: "sip:username<domain_separator>jabber_server@gateway_domain". The address of a SIP client has the following pattern : "sip_username<domain_separator>openser_domain@xmpp_domain";

section.title: gateway_domain (string)
section.para: The domain of the gateway, which must resolve. It must be the same with the gateway_domain from the destination address of the XMPP(jabber) client, as seen by the SIP client: "sip:username<delim>jjabber_server@gateway_domain".

section.title: xmpp_domain (string)
section.para: The xmpp domain of the component or the server, depending on the mode we are in. It can be the same as the gateway_domain.

section.title: xmpp_host (string)
section.para: The ip address or the name of the local jabber server, if the backend is set to "component"; or the address to bind to in the server mode.

section.title: xmpp_port (integer)
section.para: In the component mode, this is the port of the jabber router we connect to. In the server mode, it is the transport address to bind to.

para.emphasis: Default value is "5347", if backend is set to "component" and "5269", if backend is set to "server".

section.title: xmpp_password (string)
section.para: The password of the local jabber server.

para.emphasis: Default value is "secret"; if changed here, it must also be changed in the c2s.xml, added by the jabber server. This is how the default configuration for the jabberd2 looks like:
para.programlisting:
<router>
	............... 
	<!-- Username/password to authenticate as -->
    <user>jabberd</user>;          <!-- default: jabberd -->;
    <pass>secret</pass>;           <!-- default: secret -->;

section.title: outbound_proxy (string)
section.para: The SIP address used as next hop when sending the message. Very useful when using OpenSER with a domain name not in DNS, or when using a separate OpenSER instance for xmpp processing. If not set, the message will be sent to the address in destination URI.
Converts SIP messages to XMPP(jabber) messages, in order to be relayed to a XMPP(jabber) client.
